issue.title: "Optimized" CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE should possibly be renamed to Release
issue.body:
The cmake profile `Optimized` to build with `-O2` etc, seems to break CMake convention. The Rust ``cmake`` crate has a [automatic profile selection](https://docs.rs/cmake/0.1.42/cmake/struct.Config.html#method.profile) that expects ``Release`` instead of ``Optimized``.

This seems to match https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/variable/CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE.html, which also suggests that #652 was abusing ``CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`` a little bit...

comment.body:
As per suggestion by @xvzcf that I support:
>My initial thoughts are that we should add another #define/CMake option to differentiate between portable and non-portable optimized builds

--> It would be good to decide what shall be 'Release' then: An optimised version running on all platforms OR an optimised version (possibly crashing on platforms without suitable CPU extensions). In any case it would be good to have CMAKE_BUILD_TYPES specifying either as a variant without dynamic CPU feature runtime checks is markedly faster.

issue.title: Overhauled CPU-extension detection.
issue.body:
Refactored .CMake/alg_support.cmake, and kem/ and sig/ CMakeLists.txt files.

Refactored copy_from_pqclean/ templating.

Added custom x64 CPU extension detection code and removed cpu_features.

Removed duplicate Kyber source directories.

In another PR, I will add: Detection for MSVC intrinsics, a fix for https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/695, more refactoring of kem/ and sig/ CMakeLists.txt files.

comment.body: @xvzcf Yes on both items: 1) see my comment in issue #695 and 2) picking out which files are most important, can we have a quick call today to close this out most efficiently? Just ping me via Skype when you have time.

issue.title: Windows Issues
issue.body:
On my Windows 10 Enterprise VM, with with Ninja build tool and MSVC compiler. Target platform as reported by `speed_sig`: AMD64-Windows-10.0.18363.

1) Using 32-bit `cl.exe`, the build fails with the following messages:

![sike_fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21228961/78150570-77b17b00-7405-11ea-944b-869260ec974c.png)

For 64-bit builds:

2) `Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic` keypair generation takes 71.156 seconds, as measured by `speed_sig`. Signing takes 35.61 seconds. It once increased the runtime of `ninja run_tests` by 10 minutes, but this seems to be non-deterministic.

3) The SPHINCS and Rainbow variants seem in general to impose a big slow down on `ninja run_tests`.

4) `kat_sig` with `Falcon-512` and `Falcon-1024` results in heap corruption errors.

comment.body:
It was a VM image with 4G of RAM assigned to it. 

I tried running `kat_sig Falcon-512` and `kat_sig Falcon-1024` again, and both worked fine. It is likely [this change](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/commit/854f0748083b29bc9f180c8794fa112bcd7ec76d#diff-f80917420951d6ebd4388e26ee05302dR133) that fixed the problem.

issue.title: "Optimized" CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE should possibly be renamed to Release
issue.body:
The cmake profile `Optimized` to build with `-O2` etc, seems to break CMake convention. The Rust ``cmake`` crate has a [automatic profile selection](https://docs.rs/cmake/0.1.42/cmake/struct.Config.html#method.profile) that expects ``Release`` instead of ``Optimized``.

This seems to match https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/variable/CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE.html, which also suggests that #652 was abusing ``CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE`` a little bit...

comment.body: I correct myself: I just repeated the performance tests with and without run-time status tests on HEAD and the performance drop due to those bit-status tests is much smaller than I had seen before. So I rest my case: "Optimised" and "Portable" could well be the same thing: @xvzcf Please do more relevant things before looking into this micro-improvement.

issue.title: Merged upstream tag 1.1.1f
issue.body: Merges upstream tag `OpenSSL_1_1_1f`. Fixes issue #161, deprecates PR #164.

issue.title: Compiling .so file on linux (WSL)
issue.body:
Hi guys! Love the project thanks for everything! I have been trying to build the Linux binary on Windows Linux (WSL Ubuntu Bionic Beaver), but for some reason it only creates 1 lib file "liboqs.a"

Where is the ".so" file?

Here is my build commands:
1. (I have all these installed) - cmake gcc ninja-build libssl-dev python3-pytest python3-pytest-xdist unzip xsltproc doxygen graphviz
2. git clone -b master https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git
3. cd liboqs
4. mkdir build && cd build
5. cmake -GNinja ..
6. ninja

this creates a folder "lib" containing the file "liboqs.a" but no file called "liboqs.so"


**EDIT**

Nevermind I re-read the instructions for "liboqs-python" and saw that you have to use the `-DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON` flag on the pre-build command `cmake -GNinja ..` to make the output not just the static library so the new command is `cmake -GNinja -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON ..`

You guys can close this issue if you want.

comment.body: For future reference, all CMake build options for customizing liboqs are listed in [the wiki](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Customizing-liboqs).
